results.title: Alternator 15
results.brief_description: With the tendency of cars to be fitted with more electrical equipment it is becoming increasingly important to fit an alternator rather than a dynamo. This film examines the advantages of an alternator and shows research, aided by computers, into the most acceptable design

results.title: Alphabet
results.creator_credit: Eliot Noyes, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An amusing and energetic romp through the letters of the alphabet, wittily animated by Elliot Noyes Junior. Each letter has its own objects, animals or actions to suggest words it begins - A for Apple, Z for Zebra. None, however, retains the expected form for long, fading, changing at the artist’s whimsy. For anyone at the reading-readiness stage, young or old, this is a language film to sharpen words and humour.

results.title: Alouette, Canada's first satellite
results.creator_credit: C R Yool, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Design, construction, function, and launching of Canada’s first earth satellite. On the other side of the ionosphere, Alouette tracks the solar disturbances that affect radio communication and transmits much useful information for research purposes. Uses animated diagrams.

results.title: Along these lines
results.brief_description: A history of the way in which language enlarged the communication capacity of the human animal and how the telephone expanded and transformed the functions of language. Made for the Bell Telephone Company in Canada.

results.title: Allures
results.brief_description: Abstract animation by Jordon Belson. Intended to express “the subliminal rhythms of the inner cosmos”, this experimental film portrays an hallucinogenic voyage into outer space. It consists of sequences featuring interplay of dots, lines, planes, intricate kaleidoscopic designs, circles, grids, rhythms, textures, intensities and variations of focus. The images themselves often suggest the infinity of outer space or of subatomic particles, the snappy impersonality of computers or the undulation of romantic coloured clouds, provide filmed contrasts and tensions complemented by a musical soundtrack which itself acts as a counterpoint.

results.title: Allegro non troppo
results.brief_description: A parody of the Disney film “Fantasia”, “Allegro non troppo” features the highly creative work of talented Italian animator Bruno Bozzetto. It transcends the genre of parody to become a beautiful film in its own right. There are six animated sequences set to classical music, linked together by live-action scenes subtitled in English. The all-female orchestra is composed of old women and directed by a mad conductor (Maurizio Nichetti). This version features ten minutes of previously unreleased music and includes the music of Debussy, Dvorak, Ravel, Sibelius, Vivaldi and Stravinsky.

results.title: Aluminium in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: This film tells of the mining of bauxite deposits at Weipa in the far north of Australia - the York Peninsula. The product of this vast mining venture is then transported to Tasmania where it is processed into ingots at the Bell Bay Refinery. From ingots through the rolling mills it is processed into suitable form for the making of a variety of finished products for industry, the home and for commercial buildings. The enormous possibilities of the use of this light, versatile twentieth century metal are shown.
